definition: How participants decide when to rely on or question AI output
inclusion: Mentions of matching confidence or judgment to perceived reliability of AI
exclusion: Generic comments on 'trusting technology' without decision context
examples: 'I double-check the AI only when I feel uncertain about the task.'

definition: Reactions to or needs for AI explanations or reasoning visibility
inclusion: Mentions of wanting to understand why AI produced an answer
exclusion: UI preferences unrelated to reasoning transparency
examples: 'If it told me *why* it rated this résumé higher, I'd trust it more.'

definition: Value placed on human skill, intuition, or domain expertise compared to AI
inclusion: Mentions of human judgment or experience outweighing AI output
exclusion: General trust statements with no contrast to AI
examples: 'My years of hiring experience still matter more than any model.'

definition: Beliefs about AI making processes faster or more efficient
inclusion: Statements linking AI use to saved time or simplified workflow
exclusion: Comments on speed that reflect anxiety or overload, not efficiency
examples: 'Screening used to take hours; now it’s five minutes.'

definition: Concerns about inclusion, bias, or accessibility in AI systems
inclusion: Mentions of disability, bias, equal opportunity, usability barriers
exclusion: Abstract fairness talk unrelated to marginalized users
examples: 'The tool ignores gaps in employment due to disability.'

definition: Participant reflections on their own bias, feelings, or positionality
inclusion: Explicit awareness of their stance or limitations
examples: 'Maybe I’m more skeptical because I work in HR.'

definition: Ambiguous or unclear segment that doesn't fit existing codes
exclusion: Clear thematic content already covered by other codes
examples: 'I'm not sure, maybe it helps, maybe it doesn’t.'
